findings.title: AAO - Accumulated Amount Overflow
findings.description: The contract could lead to an overflow when the total value of a variable exceeds the maximum value that can be stored in that variable's data type.

findings.title: RC - Redundant Calculations
findings.description: Redundant calculations can occur in various forms in a smart contract, such as repetitive calculations for the same result, the recalculation of unchanging values, and the repeated execution of complex computations. These redundant calculations can significantly increase the gas cost of executing the smart contract.

findings.title: NWA - Non-Guaranteed Withdrawal Amount
findings.description: As part of the swap functionality, the contract deposits the `amountIn` to the vault if the token is stable or withdraws the `amountOut` from the vault and transfers it to the recipient. But since the token was never stable, no amount was deposited to the vault previously. As a result, the transaction will revert.

findings.title: MT - Mints Tokens
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to mint tokens. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `mint` function. As a result, the contract tokens will be highly inflated.

findings.title: FBC - Fees Boundaries Check
findings.description: The contract allows setting any value as `_transferFee` which can cause the burned amount to exceed the transferred amount, leading to transaction failure.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Non-conformance to Solidity naming conventions can lead to decreased readability and maintainability of the code.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The contract does not specify a stable compiler version, which may lead to unexpected behavior and potential vulnerabilities due to incompatible compiler versions.

findings.title: EIS - Excessively Integer Size
findings.description: The contract uses a bigger unsigned integer data type than necessary, consuming more storage space and requiring additional computational resources.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: FUI - Fee Update Inconsistency
findings.description: When the approved method is executed, the token fees variable is updated according to the `pairs[_token].fees` value. Hence, when the token is approved the `pairs[token]` fees are synchronized with the token's fees. The `modifyFees()` method updates the `pairs[token]` fees. If the token is approved, it may create inconsistency in the states since the `pairs[token].fees` will be different from the token's fees.

findings.title: MMN - Misleading Method Naming
findings.description: Methods can have misleading names if their names do not accurately reflect the functionality they contain or the purpose they serve.

findings.title: MSC - Missing Sanity Check
findings.description: The contract is processing variables that have not been properly sanitized and checked that they form the proper shape. These variables may produce vulnerability issues.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of certain variables without checking if their current state is equal to the one passed as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: DST - Duplicate Stable Tokens
findings.description: The `addStable` function does not check if a token has already been added to the `stableList`, resulting in potential duplicate token addresses.

findings.title: DKO - Delete Keyword Optimization
findings.description: The contract resets variables to the default state by setting the initial values, increasing gas cost.

findings.title: OO - Operator Optimization
findings.description: The `_base` and `_quote` variables can be optimized by modifying the `>` operator to `!=` operator since their values are always greater than or equal to zero.

findings.title: PEO - Pair Existence Optimization
findings.description: The contract performs certain validations to check if a pair exists or not. This check could be optimized to a single validation.

findings.title: RVC - Redundant Variable Casting
findings.description: The contract casts the `block.timestamp` variable to a 256-bit unsigned integer, which is redundant since it already has that type.

findings.title: MVN - Misleading Variables Naming
findings.description: Variables can have misleading names if their names do not accurately reflect the value they contain or the purpose they serve.

findings.title: MU - Modifiers Usage
findings.description: The contract is using repetitive statements on some methods to validate preconditions instead of using modifiers which can reduce code duplication and improve readability.

findings.title: FCI - Fees Condition Inconsistency
findings.description: The contract demonstrates an inconsistency between the validation checks regarding the `_fees` variable. The `addPair` and `modifyFees` function which include these checks do not execute the same validation check.

findings.title: RVD - Redundant Variable Declaration
findings.description: The contract stores the address of the `Vault` contract in a separate variable. Getting the address of a contract can be done by using the `address` solidity function. As a result, the variable's declaration is redundant.
